Mercury Cadmium Telluride.name: Mercury Cadmium Telluride
Mercury Cadmium Telluride.description: II-VI alloy semiconductor with bandgap tuned via Cadmium mole fraction (x). Key material for high-performance SWIR/MWIR/LWIR detectors, typically requiring cryogenic cooling. Preferred substrate: CdZnTe (~4% Zn).

safety.toxicity: High (Contains Hg, Cd). Follow strict safety protocols.
safety.handling: Requires PPE, fume hood/glovebox, hazardous waste disposal.

identification.phase_diagram_notes: Pseudo-binary. Narrow liquidus-solidus gap. Critical Hg partial pressure control needed during processing.

advanced_fabrication_insights.stoichiometry_control: Major challenge due to high Hg vapor pressure. Requires precise temperature control and Hg overpressure sources/management in MBE, MOCVD, and especially annealing.
advanced_fabrication_insights.common_defects_impact: Hg vacancies (acceptor-like, reduced lifetime), Te precipitates/inclusions (shunting paths, noise), dislocations (from substrate mismatch, affect lifetime/noise). Defect density impacts device yield and performance.
advanced_fabrication_insights.surface_preparation: Substrate cleaning and preparation (oxide removal, etch) is critical before epitaxy for nucleation and interface quality. HgCdTe surface easily damaged.
advanced_fabrication_insights.method_specific_notes: LPE: Simpler, Te-rich melts limit max 'x', potential for melt carry-over. MBE: Lower temps, precise layer control, UHV requirement. MOCVD: Conformal growth, precursor stability/purity challenges (esp. Hg).

growth_fabrication_properties.common_growth_methods: LPE, MBE, MOCVD, Bulk (Bridgman - less common for arrays).
growth_fabrication_properties.source_materials_purity: Elemental Hg, Cd, Te (typically >6N purity essential).
growth_fabrication_properties.preferred_substrates_orientations: Substrate: CdZnTe (~4% Zn) optimal; Si, GaAs, Ge also used (w/ buffers). Orientation: (111)B for LPE; (211)B, (100) for MBE/MOCVD.
growth_fabrication_properties.typical_growth_parameters: Method/x dependent. Rates: ~1-5 um/hr (MBE/MOCVD). Requires precise Temp/Pressure control.
growth_fabrication_properties.passivation_methods: Essential. Common: ZnS, CdTe, SiO2 via Sputtering, MBE, ALD etc.

post_growth_processing.annealing: CRITICAL step. Purpose: Reduce Hg vacancies, activate p-dopants (As), improve crystallinity. Temps: ~200-450C. Requires Hg overpressure.
post_growth_processing.lapping_polishing: Lapping: Al2O3/SiC slurries. Polishing: Fine diamond slurries (<1um) or CMP (e.g., Br-Methanol). Use low pressure (brittle).
post_growth_processing.etching: Wet: Br-Methanol, Br-Ethylene Glycol, Acid mixes. Dry: RIE/ICP (CH4/H2, Ar, Halogens) for patterning.
post_growth_processing.grinding_milling: Generally avoided for wafers. Possible for source prep.

band_gap.notes: Tunable via x. Target: x≈0.2 LWIR (~0.1eV), x≈0.3 MWIR (~0.25eV).

bandgap_equation.hansen_eg: Eg(x,T) Empirical Eq. (See Hansen et al.)

electrical_properties.common_dopants: n-type: In (10^14-10^16 cm^-3). p-type: As, Au, Hg-vacancies (10^15-10^17 cm^-3).

carrier_concentration.notes: Strong Temp. dependence. Extrinsic via doping.

optical_properties.spectral_range: SWIR, MWIR, LWIR (0.8 um to >30 um)

refractive_index.notes: High index. Varies with λ, x.

responsivity.notes: At 77K. Depends on λ, bias, etc.

operating_temperature.notes: Reduces dark current for optimal S/N.

chemical_properties.stability_oxidation: Surface unstable without passivation; readily oxidizes.
chemical_properties.etching: Wet: Br-Methanol, Br-Ethylene Glycol, Acid mixes. Dry: RIE/ICP (CH4/H2, Ar, Halogens).

comparison_alternatives.vs_InSb: HgCdTe offers wider spectral tuning (esp. LWIR), higher operating temps possible for MWIR. InSb often cheaper, mature tech for MWIR.
comparison_alternatives.vs_QWIPs: HgCdTe generally has higher QE and operating temps than GaAs-based QWIPs, but QWIPs have excellent uniformity and lower cost potential.
comparison_alternatives.vs_T2SLs: Type-II Superlattices (e.g., InAs/GaSb) are a major competitor, offering potentially better uniformity, lower dark currents (higher op. temps), and reduced Auger recombination, but growth/processing is complex.

references_further_reading.book_rogozkin: Rogalski, A. 'Infrared Detectors' (SPIE Press) - Comprehensive overview.
references_further_reading.review_hansen: Hansen, G. L., Schmit, J. L., & Casselman, T. N. (1982). J. Appl. Phys. 53, 7099 - Seminal paper on Eg(x,T).
references_further_reading.review_norton: Norton, P. R. (2002). Opto-Electron. Rev., 10(3), 159 - HgCdTe detector overview.
